item.title: Abercrombie & Fitch ex-CEO accused of exploiting men for sex
item.description: An organised network recruited men for sex with Abercrombie & Fitch’s then-CEO - BBC investigation.

item.title: How Mike Jeffries used shirtless models to sell Abercrombie
item.description: The Californian Mike Jeffries had a clear vision when he took over - "We go after the cool kids."

item.title: Explosion at Oxfordshire recycling plant after lightning strike
item.description: Images and video shared online show the sky to the north-west of Oxford light up with flames.

item.title: Don't give up on HS2, Tory mayor Andy Street urges Rishi Sunak
item.description: Downing Street continues to insist no final decision on the high-speed rail link to Manchester has been made.

item.title: Right-wing Republican files bid to oust McCarthy
item.description: Matt Gaetz files bid to oust Kevin McCarthy as Speaker of US House, setting up a vote within 48 hours.

item.title: Webb telescope finds floating planet-like objects in Orion
item.description: The new space observatory sees pairs of Jupiter-sized objects floating free between the stars.

item.title: Greenland women seek compensation over involuntary birth control
item.description: Some 4,500 women were fitted with coils as part of attempts to limit the territory's population.

item.title: Defiant Trump turns up at $250m New York fraud trial to blast 'scam'
item.description: The ex-president lambasts a case that could see him lose control of Trump Tower and other properties.

item.title: Oil cartel leader warns of prolonged high prices
item.description: The Secretary General says further investment in oil is needed to meet rising global energy demand.

item.title: Ukraine war: Burger King still open in Russia despite pledge to exit
item.description: The owner of the fast-food brand says there are "no new updates" on its pledge to leave Russia.

item.title: Food prices see first fall for two years as stores compete
item.description: Competition among supermarkets led to the first monthly drop in food prices since 2021, an industry body says.

item.title: Mum fears her son could die waiting for life changing surgery
item.description: A mother tells BBC Spotlight she fears her son could die waiting for life changing surgery

item.title: Watch: 128-year-old mummy finally gets a funeral
item.description: Fondly called 'Stoneman Willie,' the mummy is an icon in the history of Reading, Pennsylvania.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: 'Tory rebellion' as Sunak 'brings axe down on HS2'
item.description: Concerns over the HS2 rail project's future dominate Tuesday's front pages.

item.title: Migrants trying to reach the UK cross the Alps on foot
item.description: More than 130,000 migrants have entered Italy this year. Many try to head further into Europe.

item.title: UK weather: Will October be as unusually warm as September?
item.description: BBC Weather's Helen Willetts takes a look at the temperatures for the week ahead.

item.title: Can Meta’s new VR headset stop me feeling sick?
item.description: The company's new VR headset retails at $499 - but can Mark Zuckerberg stop it making me nauseous?

item.title: WSL: As women's football breaks records, can it also break barriers?
item.description: Can the sport capitalise on its record-breaking interest to address some of the problems players face?

item.title: What is the minimum wage and how much is it?
item.description: The national living wage is expected to go up next April, boosting two million people's pay.

item.title: The people going 'monk mode' to limit social media use
item.description: A growing number of individuals are using apps to block access to social media and the internet.

item.title: Liverpool vs Tottenham VAR Q&A: What do the Reds want? What happens now?
item.description: BBC Sport looks at key questions around the VAR incident involving Tottenham and Liverpool and what impact the technology has had on the game.

item.title: Why your new Apple iPhone 15 is overheating
item.description: The firm says a bug in its operating system and updates to apps like Instagram are behind the issue.

item.title: Malaria vaccine big advance against major child killer
item.description: Deals are in place to make 100 million doses of the vaccine each year to fight the complex disease.

item.title: Bradley Lowery: Man pleads guilty to taunting fans
item.description: Dale Houghton was pictured laughing as he brandished the image during a match against Sunderland.

item.title: Not all renters smoke weed or are in gangs, minister says
item.description: Rachel Maclean defends plans to strengthen renters’ rights at the Conservative Party conference.

item.title: PC thought he smelled cannabis in athletes' car, misconduct hearing told
item.description: Ricardo Dos Santos and Bianca Williams were stopped by police in west London in July 2020.

item.title: Sheffield City Council write apology to tree campaigners
item.description: Sheffield's Streets Ahead programme aimed to fell 17,500 street trees, leading to sustained protest.

item.title: Olivia Rodrigo: Guts album track inspired by best friend Madison Hu
item.description: The singer tells Radio 1's Live Lounge best friend Madison Hu was the "muse" for Guts song Logical.

item.title: Watch: Double rainbow and lightning strikes caught on camera
item.description: Stunning cell phone video captured a meteorological phenomenon: lightning beside a double rainbow.

item.title: Former Manchester City and England striker Francis Lee dies aged 79
item.description: Former Manchester City and England striker Francis Lee dies at the age of 79.

item.title: Pakistan police bust organ trafficking ring that took kidneys from hundreds
item.description: The alleged leader is accused of illegally harvesting kidneys from more than 300 people in Pakistan.

item.title: UK sees joint warmest September on record
item.description: Temperatures through September were well above average following a heatwave early in the month.

item.title: Fulham 0-2 Chelsea: Mykhailo Mudryk & Armando Broja on target for Blues
item.description: Mykhaylo Mudryk scores his first Chelsea goal as the Blues beat Fulham to climb to 11th in the Premier League.

item.title: Manchester United: Sir Jim Ratcliffe considering minority stake offer
item.description: Sir Jim Ratcliffe's Ineos Group is considering whether to offer to buy a minority stake in Manchester United in an effort to break the impasse over the ownership situation.

item.title: Francis Lee: 'One of Manchester City's most important figures'
item.description: Francis Lee will be regarded as one of the most important figures in the history of Manchester City, writes BBC Sport's Phil McNulty.

item.title: Garth Crooks' Team of the Week: Johnstone, Dawson, Lockyer, Andersen, Bissouma and more
item.description: Which players impressed our football pundit Garth Crooks enough to make his seventh Team of the Week?

item.title: Liverpool: Jamie Carragher says situation surrounding VAR 'at crisis point'
item.description: Former Liverpool defender Jamie Carragher says the situation surrounding the video assistant referee "is at crisis point" after Luis Diaz's disallowed goal in the defeat at Tottenham.

item.title: Francis Lee: Former Manchester City, England, Bolton and Derby striker dies aged 79
item.description: BBC Sport looks back at the career of former Manchester City and England striker Francis Lee who has died aged 79.

item.title: Cricket World Cup: England beat Bangladesh in final warm-up; New Zealand edge South Africa
item.description: England finalise their preparation for their 50-over World Cup defence with a four-wicket win over Bangladesh in Guwahati.

item.title: What is happening to house prices, and could there be a crash?
item.description: How higher interest rates are changing the UK's housing market.

item.title: Mortgages: What happens if I am struggling to pay?
item.description: Many homeowners are worried about higher mortgage costs, but lenders must help those struggling.

item.title: First time home buyers: How much can I borrow?
item.description: With rents rising, more people are crunching the numbers to see if they can afford to buy.

item.title: Train strikes: What days in October will rail travel be disrupted?
item.description: Train drivers are set to strike again, and London Underground staff are also taking action.

item.title: How to get a job: Six expert tips for finding work
item.description: There are 10m people out of work in the UK, so if you're searching for a job you're not alone. Here are some tips on how to get started.

item.title: Energy price cap: What is it and will bills continue to go down?
item.description: The price cap which sets typical annual household energy bills is falling slightly from October.

item.title: Energy bills: What can I do if I can't afford to pay?
item.description: If you're struggling to afford your gas and electricity bills, what options are available?

item.title: Energy saving tips: Five ways to cut costs this winter
item.description: Energy prices will be lower this coming winter - but you may be able to save even more on your bill.

item.title: Rent increases: What you can do about a rise from your landlord
item.description: The BBC's Lora Jones tells you four things you can do, if your landlord asks for more money.

item.title: Interest rates: How the Bank of England's decision affects you and your money
item.description: The Bank of England has held interest rates at 5.25%, bringing a run of 14 consecutive rises to an end.

item.title: Five ways to save money on your packed lunch
item.description: Grabbing food on the go can be expensive so here are some top tips on making savings at lunchtime.

item.title: Food prices: How can I save money on my grocery shop?
item.description: The cost-of-living crisis continues to bite. Here are some things that can reduce the impact.

item.title: What is GDP and how is it measured?
item.description: A basic guide to how the economy is measured and why that calculation matters.

item.title: What is the UK inflation rate and why is it so high?
item.description: The rate at which prices are rising has fallen but remains well above the 2% inflation target.

item.title: Debt: What should I pay first and what can I do?
item.description: What help and options are available to people struggling with debt repayments?

item.title: How to save money even when the budget is tight
item.description: The interest paid on savings is better than anything seen for years, so how can you save when bills are rising?

item.title: Rent prices: How much have they gone up in your area?
item.description: Use our interactive tool to find out what the average rent is in your area.

item.title: Cost-of-living payments: Who is getting them and when?
item.description: Low-income households, pensioners and some disabled people will get extra help with energy bills.

item.title: Cost of living: Five tips when asking for a pay rise
item.description: Recruiters, a manager and a workplace psychologist give their advice on how to negotiate for more money.

item.title: Renting: What are your rights as a tenant?
item.description: With one in five people now renting in the UK, it's important to understand your rights as a tenant.
